Coulombs law

The force

F\bf{\it{F}}F

on a point charge

q1q_1q1​

at the point

r1\bf{r_1}r1​

caused by a point charge

q2q_2q2​

at the point

r2\bf{r_2}r2​
F=q1q24πε0∣r1−r2∣2(r1−r2)∣r1−r2∣F = \frac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 |r_1 - r_2|^2}\frac{(r_1-r_2)}{|r_1-r_2|}F=4πε0​∣r1​−r2​∣2q1​q2​​∣r1​−r2​∣(r1​−r2​)​

Electrical Potential

E=−∇V\bm{E} = -\bm{\nabla}VE=−∇V

From pointsource

qqq

in

r′\bm{r}'r′
V(r)=q4πϵ0RV(\bm{r}) = \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}V(r)=4πϵ0​Rq​

From charge distribution

V(r)=∫14πϵ0Rdq(r′)V(\bm{r}) = \int\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}dq(\bm{r}')V(r)=∫4πϵ0​R1​dq(r′)

From point dipole

p=pez\bm{p} = p\bm{e}_zp=pez​
V(r)=p⋅r4πϵ0r3=pcos⁡(θ)4πϵ0r2V(\bm{r}) = \frac{\bm{p} \cdot \bm{r} }{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^3} = \frac{p\cos(\theta)}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^2}V(r)=4πϵ0​r3p⋅r​=4πϵ0​r2pcos(θ)​

From line charge

ρl\rho_lρl​

Where

D\bm DD

is defined by

∇D=ρ\bm\nabla \bm D = \rho∇D=ρ

Gauss law, where

en\bm e_nen​

is the unit normal to the volume surface pointing outwards

P,E\bm P, \bm EP,E

and

D\bm DD

{D=ϵ0E+P(valid generally)D=ϵrϵ0E\begin{cases} \bm D = \epsilon_0\bm E + \bm P \qquad(\textup{valid generally}) \\ \bm D = \epsilon_r\epsilon_0\bm E \end{cases}{D=ϵ0​E+P(valid generally)D=ϵr​ϵ0​E​

Polarization Charge

ρp=−∇⋅Pspace charge density\rho_p = -\bm\nabla\cdot\bm P \qquad \textup{space charge density}ρp​=−∇⋅Pspace charge density
ρp,s=en1⋅(P1−P2)surface charge density\rho_{p,s} = \bm e_{n1}\cdot(\bm P_1 - \bm P_2) \qquad \textup{surface charge density}ρp,s​=en1​⋅(P1​−P2​)surface charge density

where the unit normal

en1\bm e_{n1}en1​

is directed from 1 to 2.

Boundary Conditions

{Et  continuousρs=en2⋅(D1−D2)\begin{cases} E_t \;\textup{continuous} \\ \rho_s = \bm e_{n2}\cdot(\bm D_1 - \bm D_2) \end{cases}{Et​continuousρs​=en2​⋅(D1​−D2​)​

where

ρs\rho_sρs​

is free surface charge density and

en2\bm e_{n2}en2​

is directed from volume 2 to volume 1.

Electrostatic Energy

We=12∑iQiViW_e = \frac 12 \sum_iQ_iV_iWe​=21​i∑​Qi​Vi​
We=12∫ρV dvW_e = \frac 12 \int\rho V\: dvWe​=21​∫ρVdv
We=12∫E⋅D dvW_e = \frac 12 \int\bm E\cdot\bm D \: dvWe​=21​∫E⋅Ddv

Maxwell's voltage

∣T∣=12E⋅DE is a bisector to en and T|\bm T| = \frac 12\bm E\cdot\bm D \qquad \bm E \textup{ is a bisector to } \bm e_n \textup{ and } \bm T∣T∣=21​E⋅DE is a bisector to en​ and T

Torque on Electrical Dipole

Te=p×E\bm T_e = \bm p\times\bm ETe​=p×E
